Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of MoFlo XDP FACS Sorter
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to The University of Texas at El Paso to acquire a Fluorescence Activated Cell Sorter (FACS), a shared instrument to facilitate education and research in the region. The FACS instrument will support a diverse range of research and teaching applications across multiple disciplines in the natural sciences. The FACS instrument will be used to identify, isolate and purify multiple cell types and cell components. These FACS-purified samples will further the research programs of at least 23 faculty that seek to understand plant and animal development, microbial infectivity, environmental microbial metabolism as well as the mechanisms behind immune and cancer cell function and development, mechanisms of disease progression, ecological communities, and subcellular components ultimately benefiting our region and the public in general.

This instrument will provide access to state-of-the-art FACS instrumentation to the next generation of scientists through incorporation into science curriculum and new course development. Experiments using FACS will be employed in undergraduate teaching laboratories, bringing this advanced technology to ~400 students annually in the fields of cell biology, microbiology and molecular genetics. FACS techniques will also be introduced to graduate students for incorporation into their research projects. Placement of the FACS instrument in the Cytometry, Screening and Imaging Core Facility will facilitate management of use by multiple faculty and students. Cell sorting capabilities will facilitate recruitment, cancer development retention, collaboration, and training of both students and research faculty in the STEM disciplines and introduce this sophisticated technology to the region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award is for the acquisition of a flow cytometric MoFlo XDP FACS sorter to be placed in the Cytometry, Screening, and Imaging Core Facility at The University of Texas at El Paso. Through negotiation and competitive bidding, we have purchased a MoFlo Astrios (an upgrade of the XDP with 13 color parameters and enhanced sorting capabilities).  It allows for both multiparametric analysis and/or high speed sorting of multiple cell populations into as few as a single cell per well. Not only has our research programs and community collaborations been strengthened by acquisition of this instrument but so has our student learning. This instrument has been used by multiple laboratories and it has been incorporated into teaching laboratories.With increasing involvement of underrepresented minorities in research, we must see to it that their education is as thorough as other students` from major research institutions. To this extent, the technology and hands-on use of this instrument has been incorporated into a requisite undergraduate lab course of ~225 students (~80% of whom are underrepresented minorities) to this state-of-the-art technology. The acquisition of this FACS sorter greatly enhances the quality of research by our faculty, recruitment of new faculty members, and education of our undergraduate and graduate students with a high proportion of underrepresented minorities. With the acquisition of this FACS sorter, multiple labs have been able to advance their research. For the sake of time and space only a few projects are described here.

The PI, Dr. Spencer, has been able to separately purify type I and type II NKT cells in order to study the individual functions of these two cell types. His lab has optomized the assays to study the cellular interactions and these results have been presented at national conferences and are in preparation for submission to publish. The acquisition of this instrument was instrumental in the PI obtainined a $1.5M grant from the NIH to study the functions of these NKT cells as well as being granted tenure. We are now in the process of purifying these cell subsets for RNA sequencing.

A major user, Dr. Vines, has utilized the FACS sorter in order to generate stable cell lines that express various levels of CCR7. Using these cell lines, we can transplant them into animal models to determine their ability to enter the central nervous system. Molecular studies of these migratory processes are underway.

Following extensive optomization, a major user, Dr. Quintana, has successfully been able to isolate neural precursors in developing zebrafish embryos. Being able to specifically isolate these precursors will allow us to determine the processes involved in development of normal and abnormal neural cells and circuitry.

This instrument is also being used by external organizations in the region. We have initiated a new project with the Southwest Brain Bank to purify cell populations from donated brains of normal patients and those that have psychiatric and abuse disorders. Samples from these brains will be purified and subsequently analyzed by RNAseq with the goals of determining transcriptional changes that are associated with disease states.

The majority of users directly interacting with the instrument are students, both undergraduate and graduate students. Most of these students participate in the research projects of faculty. However, this instrument has also been incorporated into our Molecular Cell Biology teaching lab. Here, ~250 students/semester are introduced to this technology. in this lab, the students use cell lines and various drug treatments to analyze various aspects of cell biology, including, cell division, metabolism, viability and migration. For this, mixed populations of labeled cells are isolated and returned to the students for subsequent analysis under the microscope. This allows the students to witness the ability of this instrument to purify individual cell populations.
